BE11:16am

Company Update
January 18, 2019

This morning, the following email was sent to all Tesla employees:

As we all experienced first-hand, last year was the most challenging in Tesla’s history. However, thanks to your efforts, 2018 was also the most successful year in Tesla’s history: we delivered almost as many cars as we did in all of 2017 in the last quarter alone and nearly as many cars last year as we did in all the prior years of Tesla’s existence combined! Model 3 also became the best-selling premium vehicle of 2018 in the US. This is truly remarkable and something that few thought possible just a short time ago.

red i havent read the blurb but how did they explain away cuts yet so much demand for their cars
Excel Developer Surely Tesla needs reform, change must be welcome now that they have new-ish management. Larry Ellison etc.
BE11:16am

Looking ahead at our mission of accelerating the advent of sustainable transport and energy, which is important for all life on Earth, we face an extremely difficult challenge: making our cars, batteries and solar products cost-competitive with fossil fuels. While we have made great progress, our products are still too expensive for most people. Tesla has only been producing cars for about a decade and we’re up against massive, entrenched competitors. The net effect is that Tesla must work much harder than other manufacturers to survive while building affordable, sustainable products.

BornCynic BE - Are you sure that those two statements are not:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_exclusivity
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Blah blah. But then, this par.

BE11:16am

Sorry for all these numbers, but I want to make sure that you know all the facts and figures and understand that the road ahead is very difficult. This is not new for us – we have always faced significant challenges – but it is the reality we face. There are many companies that can offer a better work-life balance, because they are larger and more mature or in industries that are not so voraciously competitive. Attempting to build affordable clean energy products at scale necessarily requires extreme effort and relentless creativity, but succeeding in our mission is essential to ensure that the future is good, so we must do everything we can to advance the cause.

According to Inside EVs, Tesla accounted for 80% of the unit sales of EVs
(pure EVs, excluding hybrids) in the US in 2018.
Adjusted for average transaction prices, we estimate Tesla accounted for
roughly 90% of the US EV market by wallet share.
According to Inside EVs, the total US EV market increased 126% in 2018 vs.
2017.
Tesla’s US EV sales increased 282% in 2018.
Excluding Tesla, US EV sales declined 14% YoY in 2018.
Tesla accounted for 106% of the YoY growth in total US EV sales in 2018.

During 2019, we expect to see Tesla’s share of the US EV market continue to rise before the competition gradually starts chipping away. Tesla’s gap-to-competition in terms of market share may be approaching a peak.

BE11:29am

In Film - the problem child of the group, the strategy is to try to make the model more like the TV production business – where production does not start until 85% of the costs are covered from pre-sales. This business has already been significantly scaled back. From 80 titles this year (175 in 2017), it plans to manage the distribution business down to 30-40 titles a year over the next few years. These titles will be ones where eOne has a relationship with the producer giving it greater insight and control as to what it is distributing. A nice side effect of this is that it should also reduce the capital risk of the business (Films have to be paid for and marketed up front). Having withdrawn from many of its volume based output deals, outsourced much of its physical distribution and merged the sales function with television, despite this declining revenue profile, management think margins can be protected.

BE11:32am

ITV shares were down c. 6% yesterday on a broker broadcasting note talking about the decline of linear TV hitting the broadcasters and a downgrade to the Target Price. A few counterpoints

We already know 1H is likely to be impacted by Brexit – Jan / Feb are reportedly up slightly (although this may include VOD). There has been talk of March being down 25% as advertisers shift advertising spending to 2H. However, as ITV has eliminated its late booking penalties fees, there has been a trend towards advertisers booking money later and later. This may be a consequence of that (and note media buyers got the World Cup boost to ITV in June wrong by around 10-15%);
(2) This is all priced in – if we took ITV’s TV advertising revenues down 10% for 2019 (2009 was -8.3%), and didn’t assume ANY cost cutting, ITV is priced at just over 11x adjusted FY19E PE;
(3) ITV is still the only medium to deliver mass market audiences. Shows like Coronation Street, Emmerdale, I’m a Celebrity etc. are seeing stabilising or increasing absolute audience numbers;
(4) ITV is making inroads to the VOD market – 2018 VOD revenues were probably up close to 50%. We have written about this extensively but it is already improving ITV’s total advertising numbers by c. 2%. Bloomberg also stating that ITV is the top M&A target in Europe – it is for the third year in a row but it highlights its potential attractiveness.

Here's UBS.

BE11:42am

Q3 billings grows 2% to $194m (cons. $204m)
Sophos preannounced Q3 billings of $194m, up 2% y/y but 5% light of cons. Enduser grew 6% while Network shrank as
hardware sales declined (subscriptions grew). New customer activity was also weak, with billings declining modestly to c$50m
even as 9k new names were added vs 16k in H1 as MSP growth was strong but fewer larger business were won. Renewal rates
of 122% were slightly higher than Q2’s 121% and Q1’s 115%, and Sophos Central billings grew a healthy 29%. Cash EBITDA at
$50m/25.7% was up $3m y/y pointing to tight cost discipline. By region there were no variances in these patterns noted.
Expecting a modest decline in billings for the year now
Having previously guided for modest billings growth in the year, Sophos now expects a slight decline, pointing to a mid-singledigit
to low-double-digit decline in Q4. While a challenging renewal rate of 154% as a comparative had already been factored in to
guidance, the weaker trend in both new customers and hardware sales were given as the reason. With costs likely declining only
slightly q/q, it points to a cash EBITDA decline y/y in Q4.
Lack of visibility set to weigh on sentiment
The decision to lower the outlook again so soon after the last re-set and the weaker trend with new customers will likely weigh
on sentiment, even as the billings mix improved in the quarter.

#REF! I was bearish on Sophos two years ago but didn't hold my nerve. Lesson learned the hard way

BE11:43am

Sophos has pre-announced Q3 billings of $193.7m (growth of 2% in cc vs. JPMe of 5%). The company has also
provided guidance for a ‘modest decline’ in full-year constant currency billings growth, which implies midsingle
digit declines in cc billings growth for Q4 (vs. JPMe 3% cc). Consensus billings for FY19 of $791m is
likely to come down to the $755m-760m level (flat YoY cc); and there is clear risk to FY20 as well (current
consensus $891m). The company has also said that in 3Q it saw a ‘modest decline’ in billings from new
customers (vs ~6% cc growth in 1H’19). On the positive side, the renewal rate improved in the third quarter to
122% (vs. 118% in H1’19), likely helped by better cross-selling realized through the XG Firewall v17.5 (which
is integrated into Sophos Central). This is another disappointment for Sophos, and adds to the series of warnings
we have seen over the past nine months.

he IT security specialist reports 2% constant currency billings growth for Q3 FY19 to $193.7m (versus 2% in H1 FY19) and also 2% for the nine-months year-to-date, set against a challenging prior year comparable. Previously Sophos had expected “modest improvement in constant currency billings growth in H2 FY19 compared to the first half”. This now appears more of a stretch. In our view, the subdued Q3 outturn for billings and Cash EBITDA (which declined 8% YTD to $104m) implies downgrades to full year expectations, particularly around Cash EBITDA (where consensus is for $178m), without a material pick in billings in Q4, which Sophos is not guiding for in today’s statement. More positively, profitability has improved with reported operating profit of $51m YTD, compared to a prior-period loss of $25m. As expected, cash flow remained creditable, with net cash flow from operations of $100m for the nine-months YTD and unlevered free cash flow of $87m, broadly unchanged YTD. In addition, over 25,000 net new customers added YTD, including more than 9,000 in Q3, with total customers of 327,000. However, billings from new customers showed a modest decline year on year. We provisionally expect to ease down our estimates for FY19 and FY20 by c1% at the billings line and likely more for Cash EBITDA and unlevered free cash flow. Although Sophos already trades at a significant discount to its peer group on cash flow and EV/Sales metrics, we expect a negative reaction this morning.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

As a positive, visibility on 4Q forward bookings is good. Owing to low fares, RYA sees traffic growth to be a bit higher at 9%yoy to 142m pax (previously 141m). More importantly, RYA guides for slightly better-thanexpected unit cost performance and improving ancillary revenue performance through 2H19. While lower fares help RYA to gain market share, and recover from the hit to bookings in 3Q due to strikes, it remains to be seen how it will manage to keep pricing from deteriorating further. We also highlight that no mention has been made of any impact on the fuel bill, which is mainly a topic for FY20 now, and worth keeping in mind after Lufthansa lowered its FY19e fuel guidance earlier this week.

wayneJ 1. I know people who have beaten the market consistently over time.
BE11:59am

In our view, the guidance cut on fares is particularly disappointing since RYA has historically been quite cautious in its fare guidance. RYA blames overcapacity in European short haul this winter and, given its price passive/load factor active strategy, rather points towards higher traffic growth in 2H19. We highlighted the risk of lower fares persisting through FY19 in our recent Compass, wherein we see current low crude oil prices supporting capacity growth. Given our current crude forecasts and despite the recent rebound in crude prices, with pressure from fuel easing, unit revenues should be rather soft in FY19, at least for the summer. We think slowing GDP growth in key eurozone countries and in the US could also contribute to this.

BE12:01pm

BE12:02pm

1) RYA's shares have fallen almost 50% from their highs of late 2017. (2)
RYA remains the clear market leader in European aviation with best-in-class profitability and a strong balance sheet. (3) On our new EPS estimates RYA trades on a c10% P/E premium to EZJ, vs an average premium of 20% since 2005. We believe RYA deserves a bigger premium to EZJ due to its superior profit margins and RoCE. Our timing may not be perfect and the shares might drift lower given tough winter trading (fiscal Q3-Q4). But it is very rare to be able to buy RYA at current valuation levels and we see better prospects for the coming summer due to soft comps (summer 2018 saw a heatwave in N.Europe, the World Cup, and RYA strike disruption).

However, as noted above, EZJ’s historic valuation discount to RYA has largely disappeared, and mean reversion is now likely.
